dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRecordclass\u003c/strong\u003e is \u003ca href=\"http://opensource.org/licenses/MIT\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eMIT Licensed\u003c/a\u003e python library.\nIt was started as a \"proof of concept\" for the problem of fast \"mutable\"\nalternative of \u003ccode\u003enamedtuple\u003c/code\u003e (see \u003ca href=\"https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29290359/existence-of-mutable-named-tuple-in-python\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003equestion\u003c/a\u003e on \u003ca href=\"https://stackoverflow.com\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003estackoverflow\u003c/a\u003e).\nIt was evolved further in order to provide more memory saving, fast and flexible types.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRecordclass\u003c/strong\u003e library provide record/data-like classes that do not participate in cyclic \u003cem\u003egarbage collection\u003c/em\u003e (GC) mechanism by default, but support only \u003cem\u003ereference counting\u003c/em\u003e for garbage collection.\nThe instances of such classes havn't \u003ccode\u003ePyGC_Head\u003c/code\u003e prefix in the memory, which decrease their size and have a little faster path for the instance creation and deallocation.\nThis may make sense in cases where it is necessary to limit the size of the objects as much as possible, provided that they will never be part of references cycles in the application.\nFor example, when an object represents a record with fields with values of simple types by convention (\u003ccode\u003eint\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003efloat\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003estr\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003edate\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003etime\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003edatetime\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003etimedelta\u003c/code\u003e, etc.).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn order to illustrate this, consider a simple class with type hints:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"class Point:\n    x: int\n    y: int\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eclass Point:\n    x: int\n    y: int\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBy tacit agreement instances of the class \u003ccode\u003ePoint\u003c/code\u003e is supposed to have attributes \u003ccode\u003ex\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003ey\u003c/code\u003e with values of \u003ccode\u003eint\u003c/code\u003e type. Assigning other types of values, which are not subclass of \u003ccode\u003eint\u003c/code\u003e, should be considered as a violation of the agreement.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOther examples are non-recursive data structures in which all leaf elements represent a value of an atomic type.\nOf course, in python, nothing prevent you from “shooting yourself in the foot\" by creating the reference cycle in the script or application code.\nBut in many cases, this can still be avoided provided that the developer understands what he is doing and uses such classes in the codebase with care.\nAnother option is to use static code analyzers along with type annotations to monitor compliance with typehints.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe library is built on top of the base class \u003ccode\u003edataobject\u003c/code\u003e. The type of \u003ccode\u003edataobject\u003c/code\u003e is special metaclass \u003ccode\u003edatatype\u003c/code\u003e.\nIt control creation  of subclasses, which  will not participate in cyclic GC and do not contain \u003ccode\u003ePyGC_Head\u003c/code\u003e-prefix, \u003ccode\u003e__dict__\u003c/code\u003e  and \u003ccode\u003e__weakref__\u003c/code\u003e  by default.\nAs the result the instance of such class need less memory.\nIt's memory footprint is similar to memory footprint of instances of the classes with \u003ccode\u003e__slots__\u003c/code\u003e but without \u003ccode\u003ePyGC_Head\u003c/code\u003e. So the difference in memory size is equal to the size of \u003ccode\u003ePyGC_Head\u003c/code\u003e.\nIt also tunes \u003ccode\u003ebasicsize\u003c/code\u003e of the instances, creates descriptors for the fields and etc.\nAll subclasses of \u003ccode\u003edataobject\u003c/code\u003e created by \u003ccode\u003eclass statement\u003c/code\u003e support \u003ccode\u003eattrs\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003edataclasses\u003c/code\u003e-like API.\nFor example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"    from recordclass import dataobject, astuple, asdict\n    class Point(dataobject):\n        x:int\n        y:int\n\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p = Point(1, 2)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; astuple(p)\n    (1, 2)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; asdict(p)\n    {'x':1, 'y':2}\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e    from recordclass import dataobject, astuple, asdict\n    class Point(dataobject):\n        x:int\n        y:int\n\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p = Point(1, 2)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; astuple(p)\n    (1, 2)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; asdict(p)\n    {'x':1, 'y':2}\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003erecordclass\u003c/code\u003e factory create dataobject-based subclass with specified fields and the support of \u003ccode\u003enamedtuple\u003c/code\u003e-like API.\nBy default it will not participate in cyclic GC too.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; from recordclass import recordclass\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; Point = recordclass('Point', 'x y')\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p = Point(1, 2)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p.y = -1\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; print(p._astuple)\n    (1, -1)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; x, y = p\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; print(p._asdict)\n    {'x':1, 'y':-1}\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; from recordclass import recordclass\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; Point = recordclass('Point', 'x y')\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p = Point(1, 2)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p.y = -1\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; print(p._astuple)\n    (1, -1)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; x, y = p\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; print(p._asdict)\n    {'x':1, 'y':-1}\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIt also provide a factory function \u003ccode\u003emake_dataclass\u003c/code\u003e for creation of subclasses of \u003ccode\u003edataobject\u003c/code\u003e with the specified field names.\nThese subclasses support \u003ccode\u003eattrs\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003edataclasses\u003c/code\u003e-like API. It's equivalent to creating subclasses of dataobject using \u003ccode\u003eclass statement\u003c/code\u003e.\nFor example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; Point = make_dataclass('Point', 'x y')\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p = Point(1, 2)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p.y = -1\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; print(p.x, p.y)\n    1 -1\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; Point = make_dataclass('Point', 'x y')\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p = Point(1, 2)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p.y = -1\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; print(p.x, p.y)\n    1 -1\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf one want to use some sequence for initialization then:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p = Point(*sequence)\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p = Point(*sequence)\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThere is also a factory function \u003ccode\u003emake_arrayclass\u003c/code\u003e for creation of the subclass of \u003ccode\u003edataobject\u003c/code\u003e, which can be considered as a compact array of simple objects.\nFor example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; Pair = make_arrayclass(2)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p = Pair(2, 3)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p[1] = -1\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; print(p)\n    Pair(2, -1)\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; Pair = make_arrayclass(2)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p = Pair(2, 3)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p[1] = -1\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; print(p)\n    Pair(2, -1)\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe library provide in addition the classes \u003ccode\u003elightlist\u003c/code\u003e (immutable) and \u003ccode\u003elitetuple\u003c/code\u003e, which considers as list-like and tuple-like \u003cem\u003elight\u003c/em\u003e containers in order to save memory. They do not supposed to participate in cyclic GC too. Mutable variant of litetuple is called by \u003ccode\u003emutabletuple\u003c/code\u003e.\nFor example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; lt = litetuple(1, 2, 3)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; mt = mutabletuple(1, 2, 3)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; lt == mt\n    True\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; mt[-1] = -3\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; lt == mt\n    False\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; print(sys.getsizeof((1,2,3)), sys.getsizeof(litetuple(1,2,3)))\n    64 48\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; lt = litetuple(1, 2, 3)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; mt = mutabletuple(1, 2, 3)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; lt == mt\n    True\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; mt[-1] = -3\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; lt == mt\n    False\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; print(sys.getsizeof((1,2,3)), sys.getsizeof(litetuple(1,2,3)))\n    64 48\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eNote if one like create \u003ccode\u003elitetuple\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003emutabletuple\u003c/code\u003e from some iterable then:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; seq = [1,2,3]\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; lt = litetuple(*seq)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; mt = mutabletuple(*seq)\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; seq = [1,2,3]\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; lt = litetuple(*seq)\n    \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; mt = mutabletuple(*seq)\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eMemory footprint\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-memory-footprint\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Memory 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe following table explain memory footprints of the  \u003ccode\u003edataobject\u003c/code\u003e-based objects and litetuples:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"1\"\u003e\n  \u003cthead\u003e\n    \u003ctr\u003e\n 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThere is the option \u003ccode\u003edeep_dealloc\u003c/code\u003e (default value is \u003ccode\u003eFalse\u003c/code\u003e) for deallocation of recursive datastructures.\nLet consider simple example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"class LinkedItem(dataobject):\n    val: object\n    next: 'LinkedItem'\n\nclass LinkedList(dataobject, deep_dealloc=True):\n    start: LinkedItem = None\n    end: LinkedItem = None\n\n    def append(self, val):\n        link = LinkedItem(val, None)\n        if self.start is None:\n            self.start = link\n        else:\n            self.end.next = link\n        self.end = link\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eclass LinkedItem(dataobject):\n    val: object\n    next: 'LinkedItem'\n\nclass LinkedList(dataobject, deep_dealloc=True):\n    start: LinkedItem = None\n    end: LinkedItem = None\n\n    def append(self, val):\n        link = LinkedItem(val, None)\n        if self.start is None:\n            self.start = link\n        else:\n            self.end.next = link\n        self.end = link\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWithout \u003ccode\u003edeep_dealloc=True\u003c/code\u003e deallocation of the instance of \u003ccode\u003eLinkedList\u003c/code\u003e will be failed if the length of the linked list is too large.\nBut it can be resolved with \u003ccode\u003e__del__\u003c/code\u003e method for clearing the linked list:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"def __del__(self):\n    curr = self.start\n    while curr is not None:\n        next = curr.next\n        curr.next = None\n        curr = next\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003edef __del__(self):\n    curr = self.start\n    while curr is not None:\n        next = curr.next\n        curr.next = None\n        curr = next\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThere is builtin more fast deallocation method using finalization mechanizm when \u003ccode\u003edeep_dealloc=True\u003c/code\u003e. In such case one don't need \u003ccode\u003e__del__\u003c/code\u003e  method for clearing the linked list.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eNote that for classes with \u003ccode\u003egc=True\u003c/code\u003e this method is disabled: the python's cyclic GC is used in these cases.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor more details see notebook \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/intellimath/recordclass/tree/main/examples/example_datatypes.ipynb\"\u003eexample_datatypes\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv \u003ccode\u003e__match_args__\u003c/code\u003e. For example,\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"   class User(dataobject):\n       first_name: str\n       last_name: str\n       age: int\n       __match_args__ = 'first_name', 'last_name'\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e   class User(dataobject):\n       first_name: str\n       last_name: str\n       age: int\n       __match_args__ = 'first_name', 'last_name'\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eor\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"    User = make_dataclass(\u0026quot;User\u0026quot;, \u0026quot;first_name last_name * age\u0026quot;)\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e    User = make_dataclass(\"User\", \"first_name last_name * age\")\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003e@as_record\u003c/code\u003e adapter for \u003ccode\u003edef\u003c/code\u003e-style decalarations of dataclasses\nthat are considered as just a struct. For example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"  @as_record()\n  def Point(x:float, y:float, meta=None): pass\n\n  \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p = Point(1,2)\n  \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; print(p)\n  Point(x=1, y=2, meta=None)\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e  @as_record()\n  def Point(x:float, y:float, meta=None): pass\n\n  \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p = Point(1,2)\n  \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; print(p)\n  Point(x=1, y=2, meta=None)\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIt's almost equivalent to:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"  Point = make_dataclass('Point', [('x':float), ('y',float),'meta'], (None,))\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e  Point = make_dataclass('Point', [('x':float), ('y',float),'meta'], (None,))\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe option \u003ccode\u003efast_new\u003c/code\u003e will be removed in 0.22. It will be always as \u003ccode\u003efast_new=True\u003c/code\u003e by creation.\nOne can specify own \u003ccode\u003e__new__\u003c/code\u003e, for example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"  class Point(dataobject):\n      x:int\n      y:int\n\n      def __new__(cls, x=0, y=0):\n           return dataobject.__new__(cls, x, y)\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e  class Point(dataobject):\n      x:int\n      y:int\n\n      def __new__(cls, x=0, y=0):\n           return dataobject.__new__(cls, x, y)\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFix issues with \u003ccode\u003e_PyUnicodeWriter\u003c/code\u003e for python3.13.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch4 tabindex=\"-1\" For example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\" class A(dataobject, copy_default=True):\n      l: list = []\n\n a = A()\n b = A()\n assert(a.l == b.l)\n assert(id(a.l) != id(b.l))\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e class A(dataobject, copy_default=True):\n      l: list = []\n\n a = A()\n b = A()\n assert(a.l == b.l)\n assert(id(a.l) != id(b.l))\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAllow to inherit the options: \u003ccode\u003ecopy_default\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003egc\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eiterable\u003c/code\u003e. For example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\" class Base(dataobject, copy_default=True):\n    pass\n\nclass A(Base):\n      l: list = []\n\n a = A()\n b = A()\n assert a.l == b.l\n assert id(a.l) != id(b.l)\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e class Base(dataobject, copy_default=True):\n    pass\n\nclass A(Base):\n      l: list = []\n\n a = A()\n b = A()\n assert a.l == b.l\n assert id(a.l) != id(b.l)\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003eFactory\u003c/code\u003e to specify factory function for default values. For example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"  from recordclass import Factory\n  class A(dataobject):\n      x: tuple = Factory(lambda: (list(), dict()))\n\n  a = A()\n  b = A()\n  assert a.x == ([],{})\n  assert id(a.x) != id(b.x)\n  assert id(a.x[0]) != id(b.x[0])\n  assert id(a.x[1]) != id(b.x[1])\n\n  from recordclass import Factory\n  class A(dataobject, copy_default=True):\n      l: list = []\n      x: tuple = Factory(lambda: (list(), dict()))\n\n  a = A()\n  b = A()\n  assert a.x == ([],{})\n  assert id(a.x) != id(b.x)\n  assert a.l == []\n  assert id(a.l) != id(b.l)\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e  from recordclass import Factory\n  class A(dataobject):\n      x: tuple = Factory(lambda: (list(), dict()))\n\n  a = A()\n  b = A()\n  assert a.x == ([],{})\n  assert id(a.x) != id(b.x)\n  assert id(a.x[0]) != id(b.x[0])\n  assert id(a.x[1]) != id(b.x[1])\n\n  from recordclass import Factory\n  class A(dataobject, copy_default=True):\n      l: list = []\n      x: tuple = Factory(lambda: (list(), dict()))\n\n  a = A()\n  b = A()\n  assert a.x == ([],{})\n  assert id(a.x) != id(b.x)\n  assert a.l == []\n  assert id(a.l) != id(b.l)\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRecordclass \u003ccode\u003eRecordClass(name, fields, **kw)\u003c/code\u003e for class creation\nuse factory function \u003ccode\u003erecordclass(name, fields, **kw)\u003c/code\u003e\n(it allows to specify types).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAdd option api='dict'  to \u003ccode\u003emake_dataclass\u003c/code\u003e for creating class that support dict-like API.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eNow one can't remove dataobject's property from it's class using del or builting delattr.\nFor example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"  \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; Point = deleted\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e  \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; Point = make_dataclass(\"Point\", \"x y\")\n  \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; del Point.x\n  ...........\n deleted\u0026quot;\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e  \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; p = Point(1, 2)\n  \u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; del p.x\n  ...........\n  AttributeError: \u003ccode\u003estructclass\u003c/code\u003e factory function. It's analog of \u003ccode\u003erecordclass\u003c/code\u003e but with less memory\nfootprint for it's instances (same as for instances of classes with \u003ccode\u003e__slots__\u003c/code\u003e) in the camparison\nwith \u003ccode\u003erecordclass\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003enamedtuple\u003c/code\u003e\n(it currently implemented with \u003ccode\u003eCython\u003c/code\u003e).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003earrayclass\u003c/code\u003e factory function which produce a class for creation fixed size array.\nThe benefit of such approach is also less memory footprint\n(it currently currently implemented with \u003ccode\u003eCython\u003c/code\u003e).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003estructclass\u003c/code\u003e factory has argument \u003ccode\u003egc\u003c/code\u003e now. If \u003ccode\u003egc=False\u003c/code\u003e (by default) support of cyclic garbage collection\nwill switched off for instances of the created class.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd function \u003ccode\u003ejoin(C1, C2)\u003c/code\u003e in order to join two \u003ccode\u003estructclass\u003c/code\u003e-based classes C1 and C2.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd \u003ccode\u003esequenceproxy\u003c/code\u003e function for creation of immutable and hashable proxy object from class instances,\nwhich implement access by index\n(it currently currently implemented with \u003ccode\u003eCython\u003c/code\u003e).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd support for access to recordclass object attributes by idiom: \u003ccode\u003eob['attrname']\u003c/code\u003e (Issue #5).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd argument \u003ccode\u003ereadonly\u003c/code\u003e to recordclass factory to produce immutable namedtuple.\nIn contrast to \u003ccode\u003ecollection.namedtuple\u003c/code\u003e it use same descriptors as for\nregular recordclasses for performance increasing.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv 2Z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="Box-sc-g0xbh4-0 bJMeLZ js-snippet-clipboard-copy-unpositioned" data-hpc="true"><article class="markdown-body entry-content container-lg" itemprop="text"><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h1 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Recordclass library</h1><a id="user-content-recordclass-library" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Recordclass library" href="#recordclass-library"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto"><strong>Recordclass</strong> is <a href="http://opensource.org/licenses/MIT" rel="nofollow">MIT Licensed</a> python library.It was started as a "proof of concept" for the problem of fast "mutable"alternative of <code>namedtuple</code> (see <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29290359/existence-of-mutable-named-tuple-in-python" rel="nofollow">question</a> on <a href="https://stackoverflow.com" rel="nofollow">stackoverflow</a>).It was evolved further in order to provide more memory saving, fast and flexible types.</p><p dir="auto"><strong>Recordclass</strong> library provide record/data-like classes that do not participate in cyclic <em>garbage collection</em> (GC) mechanism by default, but support only <em>reference counting</em> for garbage collection.The instances of such classes havn't <code>PyGC_Head</code> prefix in the memory, which decrease their size and have a little faster path for the instance creation and deallocation.This may make sense in cases where it is necessary to limit the size of the objects as much as possible, provided that they will never be part of references cycles in the application.For example, when an object represents a record with fields with values of simple types by convention (<code>int</code>, <code>float</code>, <code>str</code>, <code>date</code>/<code>time</code>/<code>datetime</code>, <code>timedelta</code>, etc.).</p><p dir="auto">In order to illustrate this, consider a simple class with type hints:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="class Point:    x: int    y: int"><pre class="notranslate"><code>class Point:    x: int    y: int</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">By tacit agreement instances of the class <code>Point</code> is supposed to have attributes <code>x</code> and <code>y</code> with values of <code>int</code> type. Assigning other types of values, which are not subclass of <code>int</code>, should be considered as a violation of the agreement.</p><p dir="auto">Other examples are non-recursive data structures in which all leaf elements represent a value of an atomic type.Of course, in python, nothing prevent you from “shooting yourself in the foot" by creating the reference cycle in the script or application code.But in many cases, this can still be avoided provided that the developer understands what he is doing and uses such classes in the codebase with care.Another option is to use static code analyzers along with type annotations to monitor compliance with typehints.</p><p dir="auto">The library is built on top of the base class <code>dataobject</code>. The type of <code>dataobject</code> is special metaclass <code>datatype</code>.It control creation  of subclasses, which  will not participate in cyclic GC and do not contain <code>PyGC_Head</code>-prefix, <code>__dict__</code>  and <code>__weakref__</code>  by default.As the result the instance of such class need less memory.It's memory footprint is similar to memory footprint of instances of the classes with <code>__slots__</code> but without <code>PyGC_Head</code>. So the difference in memory size is equal to the size of <code>PyGC_Head</code>.It also tunes <code>basicsize</code> of the instances, creates descriptors for the fields and etc.All subclasses of <code>dataobject</code> created by <code>class statement</code> support <code>attrs</code>/<code>dataclasses</code>-like API.For example:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="    from recordclass import dataobject, astuple, asdict    class Point(dataobject):        x:int        y:int    >>> p = Point(1, 2)    >>> astuple(p)    (1, 2)    >>> asdict(p)    {'x':1, 'y':2}"><pre class="notranslate"><code>    from recordclass import dataobject, astuple, asdict    class Point(dataobject):        x:int        y:int    >>> p = Point(1, 2)    >>> astuple(p)    (1, 2)    >>> asdict(p)    {'x':1, 'y':2}</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">The <code>recordclass</code> factory create dataobject-based subclass with specified fields and the support of <code>namedtuple</code>-like API.By default it will not participate in cyclic GC too.</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="    >>> from recordclass import recordclass    >>> Point = recordclass('Point', 'x y')    >>> p = Point(1, 2)    >>> p.y = -1    >>> print(p._astuple)    (1, -1)    >>> x, y = p    >>> print(p._asdict)    {'x':1, 'y':-1}"><pre class="notranslate"><code>    >>> from recordclass import recordclass    >>> Point = recordclass('Point', 'x y')    >>> p = Point(1, 2)    >>> p.y = -1    >>> print(p._astuple)    (1, -1)    >>> x, y = p    >>> print(p._asdict)    {'x':1, 'y':-1}</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">It also provide a factory function <code>make_dataclass</code> for creation of subclasses of <code>dataobject</code> with the specified field names.These subclasses support <code>attrs</code>/<code>dataclasses</code>-like API. It's equivalent to creating subclasses of dataobject using <code>class statement</code>.For example:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="    >>> Point = make_dataclass('Point', 'x y')    >>> p = Point(1, 2)    >>> p.y = -1    >>> print(p.x, p.y)    1 -1"><pre class="notranslate"><code>    >>> Point = make_dataclass('Point', 'x y')    >>> p = Point(1, 2)    >>> p.y = -1    >>> print(p.x, p.y)    1 -1</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">If one want to use some sequence for initialization then:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="    >>> p = Point(*sequence)"><pre class="notranslate"><code>    >>> p = Point(*sequence)</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">There is also a factory function <code>make_arrayclass</code> for creation of the subclass of <code>dataobject</code>, which can be considered as a compact array of simple objects.For example:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="    >>> Pair = make_arrayclass(2)    >>> p = Pair(2, 3)    >>> p[1] = -1    >>> print(p)    Pair(2, -1)"><pre class="notranslate"><code>    >>> Pair = make_arrayclass(2)    >>> p = Pair(2, 3)    >>> p[1] = -1    >>> print(p)    Pair(2, -1)</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">The library provide in addition the classes <code>lightlist</code> (immutable) and <code>litetuple</code>, which considers as list-like and tuple-like <em>light</em> containers in order to save memory. They do not supposed to participate in cyclic GC too. Mutable variant of litetuple is called by <code>mutabletuple</code>.For example:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="    >>> lt = litetuple(1, 2, 3)    >>> mt = mutabletuple(1, 2, 3)    >>> lt == mt    True    >>> mt[-1] = -3    >>> lt == mt    False    >>> print(sys.getsizeof((1,2,3)), sys.getsizeof(litetuple(1,2,3)))    64 48"><pre class="notranslate"><code>    >>> lt = litetuple(1, 2, 3)    >>> mt = mutabletuple(1, 2, 3)    >>> lt == mt    True    >>> data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=">>> from recordclass import dataobject, asdict, astuple, as_dataclass, as_record"><pre class="notranslate"><code>>>> from recordclass import dataobject, asdict, data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="class Point(dataobject):    x: int    y: int"><pre class="notranslate"><code>class Point(dataobject):    x: int    y: int</code></pre></div><p "y",int})</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">Annotations of the fields are defined as a dict in <code>__annotations__</code>:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=">>> print(Point.__annotations__){'x': <class 'int'>, 'y': <class 'int'>}"><pre class="notranslate"><code>>>> print(Point.__annotations__){'x': <class 'int'>, 'y': <class 'int'>}</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">There is default text representation:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=">>> p = Point(1, 2)>>> print(p)Point(x=1, y=2)"><pre class="notranslate"><code>>>> p = Point(1, 2)>>> print(p)Point(x=1, y=2)</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">The instances has a minimum memory footprint that is possible for CPython object, which contain only Python objects:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=">>> sys.getsizeof(p) # the output below for python 3.8+ (64bit)40>>> p.__sizeof__() == sys.getsizeof(p) # no additional space for cyclic GC supportTrue"><pre class="notranslate"><code>>>> sys.getsizeof(p) # the output below for python 3.8+ (64bit)40>>> p.__sizeof__() == sys.getsizeof(p) # no additional space for cyclic GC supportTrue</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">The instance is mutable by default:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=">>> p_id = id(p)>>> p.x, p.y = 10, 20>>> id(p) == p_idTrue>>> print(p)Point(x=10, y=20)"><pre class="notranslate"><code>>>> p_id = id(p)>>> p.x, p.y = 10, 20>>> id(p) == p_idTrue>>> print(p)Point(x=10, y=20)</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">There are functions <code>asdict</code> and <code>astuple</code> for converting to <code>dict</code> and to <code>tuple</code>:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=">>> asdict(p){'x':10, 'y':20}>>> astuple(p)(10, 20)"><pre class="notranslate"><code>>>> asdict(p){'x':10, 'y':20}>>> astuple(p)(10, 20)</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">By default subclasses of dataobject are mutable. If one want make it immutable then there is the option <code>readonly=True</code>:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="class Point(dataobject, readonly=True):    x: int    y: int>>> p = Point(1,2)>>> p.x = -1. . . . . . . . . . . . .TypeError: item is readonly"><pre class="notranslate"><code>class Point(dataobject, readonly=True):    x: int    y: int>>> p = Point(1,2)>>> p.x = -1. . . . . . . . . . . . .TypeError: item is readonly</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">By default subclasses of dataobject are not iterable by default.If one want make it iterable then there is the option <code>iterable=True</code>:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="class Point(dataobject, iterable=True):    x: int    y: int>>> p = Point(1,2)>>> for x in p: print(x)12"><pre class="notranslate"><code>class Point(dataobject, iterable=True):    x: int    y: int>>> p = Point(1,2)>>> for x in p: print(x)12</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">Default values are also supported::</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="class CPoint(dataobject):    x: int    y: int    color: str = 'white'"><pre class="notranslate"><code>class CPoint(dataobject):    x: int    y: int    color: str = 'white'</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">or</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=">>> CPoint = make_dataclass("CPoint", [("x",int), ("y",int), ("color",str)], defaults=("white",))>>> p = CPoint(1,2)>>> print(p)Point(x=1, y=2, color='white')"><pre class="notranslate"><code>>>> CPoint = make_dataclass("CPoint", [("x",int), ("y",int), ("color",str)], defaults=("white",))>>> p = CPoint(1,2)>>> print(p)Point(x=1, y=2, color='white')</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">But</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="class PointInvalidDefaults(dataobject):    x:int = 0    y:int"><pre class="notranslate"><code>class PointInvalidDefaults(dataobject):    x:int = 0    y:int</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">is not allowed. A fields without default value may not appear after a field with default value.</p><p dir="auto">There is an option <code>copy_default</code> (starting from 0.21) in order to assign a copy of the default value when creating an instance:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=" class Polygon(dataobject, copy_default=True):    points: list = []>>> pg1 = Polygon()>>> pg2 = Polygon()>>> assert pg1.points == pg2.pointsTrue>>> assert id(pg1.points) != id(pg2.points)True"><pre class="notranslate"><code> class Polygon(dataobject, copy_default=True):    points: list = []>>> pg1 = Polygon()>>> pg2 = Polygon()>>> assert pg1.points == pg2.pointsTrue>>> assert id(pg1.points) != id(pg2.points)True</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">A <code>Factory</code> (starting from 0.21) allows you to setup a factory function to calculate the default value:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="from recordclass import Factoryclass A(dataobject, copy_default=True):    x: tuple = Factory( lambda: (list(), dict()) )>>> a = A()>>> b = A()>>> assert a.x == b.xTrue>>> assert id(a.x[0]) != id(b.x[0])True>>> assert id(a.x[1]) != id(b.x[1])True"><pre class="notranslate"><code>from recordclass import Factoryclass A(dataobject, copy_default=True):    x: tuple = Factory( lambda: (list(), dict()) )>>> a = A()>>> b = A()>>> assert a.x == b.xTrue>>> assert id(a.x[0]) != id(b.x[0])True>>> assert id(a.x[1]) != id(b.x[1])True</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">If someone wants to define a class attribute, then there is a <code>ClassVar</code> trick:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="class Point(dataobject):    x:int    y:int    color:ClassVar[int] = 0>>> print(Point.__fields__)('x', 'y')>>> print(Point.color)0"><pre class="notranslate"><code>class Point(dataobject):    x:int    y:int    color:ClassVar[int] = 0>>> print(Point.__fields__)('x', 'y')>>> print(Point.color)0</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">If the default value for the <code>ClassVar</code>-attribute is not specified,it will just be excluded from the <code>__fields___</code>.</p><p dir="auto">Starting with python 3.10 <code>__match_args__</code> is specified by default so that <code>__match_args__</code> == <code>__fields__</code>.User can define it's own during definition:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="class User(dataobject):    first_name: str    last_name: str    age: int    __match_args__ = 'first_name', 'last_name'"><pre class="notranslate"><code>class User(dataobject):    first_name: str    last_name: str    age: int    __match_args__ = 'first_name', 'last_name'</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">or</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="from recordclass import MATCHclass User(dataobject):    first_name: str    last_name: str    _: MATCH    age: int"><pre class="notranslate"><code>from recordclass import MATCHclass User(dataobject):    first_name: str    last_name: str    _: MATCH    age: int</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">or</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="User = make_dataclass("User", "first_name last_name * age")"><pre class="notranslate"><code>User = make_dataclass("User", "first_name last_name * age")</code></pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Quick start with recordclass</h3><a id="user-content-quick-start-with-recordclass" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Quick start with recordclass" href="#quick-start-with-recordclass"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The <code>recordclass</code> factory function is designed to create classes that support <code>namedtuple</code>'s API, can be mutable and immutable, provide fast creation of the instances and have a minimum memory footprint.</p><p dir="auto">First load inventory:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=">>> from recordclass import recordclass"><pre class="notranslate"><code>>>> from recordclass import recordclass</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">Example with <code>recordclass</code>:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=">>> Point = recordclass('Point', 'x y')>>> p = Point(1,2)>>> print(p)Point(1, 2)>>> print(p.x, p.y)1 2>>> p.x, p.y = 1, 2>>> print(p)Point(1, 2)>>> sys.getsizeof(p) # the output below is for 64bit cpython3.8+32"><pre class="notranslate"><code>>>> Point = recordclass('Point', 'x y')>>> p = Point(1,2)>>> print(p)Point(1, 2)>>> print(p.x, p.y)1 2>>> p.x, p.y = 1, 2>>> print(p)Point(1, 2)>>> sys.getsizeof(p) # the output below is for 64bit cpython3.8+32</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">Example with class statement and typehints:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=">>> from recordclass import RecordClassclass Point(RecordClass):   x: int   y: int>>> print(Point.__annotations__){'x': <class 'int'>, 'y': <class 'int'>}>>> p = Point(1, 2)>>> print(p)Point(1, 2)>>> print(p.x, p.y)1 2>>> p.x, p.y = 1, 2>>> print(p)Point(1, 2)"><pre class="notranslate"><code>>>> from recordclass import RecordClassclass Point(RecordClass):   x: int   y: int>>> print(Point.__annotations__){'x': <class 'int'>, 'y': <class 'int'>}>>> p = Point(1, 2)>>> print(p)Point(1, 2)>>> print(p.x, p.y)1 2>>> p.x, p.y = 1, 2>>> print(p)Point(1, 2)</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">By default <code>recordclass</code>-based class instances doesn't participate in cyclic GC and therefore they are smaller than <code>namedtuple</code>-based ones. If one want to use it in scenarios with reference cycles then one have to use option <code>gc=True</code> (<code>gc=False</code> by default):</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=">>> Node = recordclass('Node', 'root children', gc=True)"><pre class="notranslate"><code>>>> Node = recordclass('Node', 'root children', gc=True)</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">or</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="class Node(RecordClass, gc=True):     root: 'Node'     chilren: list"><pre class="notranslate"><code>class Node(RecordClass, gc=True):     root: 'Node'     chilren: list</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">The <code>recordclass</code> factory can also specify type of the fields:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=">>> Point = recordclass('Point', [('x',int), ('y',int)])"><pre class="notranslate"><code>>>> Point = recordclass('Point', [('x',int), ('y',int)])</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">or</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=">>> Point = recordclass('Point', {'x':int, 'y':int})"><pre class="notranslate"><code>>>> Point = recordclass('Point', {'x':int, 'y':int})</code></pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Using class="heading-element" dir="auto">Using dataobject-based classes for recursive data without reference cycles</h3><a id="user-content-using-dataobject-based-classes-for-recursive-data-without-reference-cycles" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Using dataobject-based classes for recursive data without reference cycles" href="#using-dataobject-based-classes-for-recursive-data-without-reference-cycles"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">There is the option <code>deep_dealloc</code> (default value is <code>False</code>) for deallocation of recursive datastructures.Let consider simple example:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="class LinkedItem(dataobject):    val: object    next: 'LinkedItem'class LinkedList(dataobject, deep_dealloc=True):    start: LinkedItem = None    end: LinkedItem = None    def append(self, val):        link = LinkedItem(val, None)        if self.start is None:            self.start = link        else:            self.end.next = link        self.end = link"><pre class="notranslate"><code>class LinkedItem(dataobject):    val: object    next: 'LinkedItem'class LinkedList(dataobject, deep_dealloc=True):    start: LinkedItem = None    end: LinkedItem = None    def append(self, val):        link = LinkedItem(val, None)        if self.start is None:            self.start = link        else:            self.end.next = link        self.end = link</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">Without <code>deep_dealloc=True</code> deallocation of the instance of <code>LinkedList</code> will be failed if the length of the linked list is too large.But it can be resolved with <code>__del__</code> method for clearing the linked list:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="def __del__(self):    curr = self.start    while curr is not None:        next = curr.next        curr.next = None        curr = next"><pre class="notranslate"><code>def __del__(self):    curr = self.start    while curr is not None:        next = curr.next        curr.next = None        curr = next</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">There is builtin more fast deallocation method using finalization mechanizm when <code>deep_dealloc=True</code>. In such case one don't need <code>__del__</code>  method for clearing the linked list.</p><blockquote><p dir="auto">Note that for classes with <code>gc=True</code> this method is disabled: the python's cyclic GC is used in these cases.</p></blockquote><p dir="auto">For more details see notebook <a href="https://github.com/intellimath/recordclass/tree/main/examples/example_datatypes.ipynb">example_datatypes</a>.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" For example:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="  @as_record()  def Point(x:float, y:float, meta=None): pass  >>> p = Point(1,2)  >>> print(p)  Point(x=1, y=2, meta=None)"><pre class="notranslate"><code>  @as_record()  def Point(x:float, y:float, meta=None): pass  >>> p = Point(1,2)  >>> print(p)  Point(x=1, y=2, meta=None)</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">It's almost equivalent to:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="  Point = make_dataclass('Point', [('x':float), ('y',float),'meta'], (None,))"><pre class="notranslate"><code>  Point = make_dataclass('Point', [('x':float), ('y',float),'meta'], (None,))</code></pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">The option <code>fast_new</code> will be removed in 0.22. It will be always as <code>fast_new=True</code> by creation.One can specify own <code>__new__</code>, for example:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="  class Point(dataobject):      x:int      y:int      def __new__(cls, x=0, y=0):           return dataobject.__new__(cls, x, y)"><pre class="notranslate"><code>  class Point(dataobject):      x:int      y:int      def __new__(cls, x=0, y=0):           return dataobject.__new__(cls, x, y)</code></pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">Fix issues with <code>_PyUnicodeWriter</code> for python3.13.</p></li></ul><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">0.21</h4><a id="user-content-021" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: 0.21" href="#021"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><ul dir="auto"><li><p dir="auto">Add a new option <code>copy_default</code> (default <code>False</code>) to allow assigning a copy of the defaultvalue for the field. It's analog of <code>recordclass</code> but with less memoryfootprint for it's instances (same as for instances of classes with <code>__slots__</code>) in the camparisonwith <code>recordclass</code> and <code>namedtuple</code>(it currently implemented with <code>Cython</code>).</li><li>Add <code>arrayclass</code> factory function which produce a class for creation fixed size array.The benefit of such approach is also less memory footprint(it currently currently implemented with <code>Cython</code>).</li><li><code>structclass</code> factory has argument <code>gc</code> now. If <code>gc=False</code> (by default) support of cyclic garbage collectionwill switched off for instances of the created class.</li><li>Add function <code>join(C1, C2)</code> in order to join two <code>structclass</code>-based classes C1 and C2.</li><li>Add <code>sequenceproxy</code> function for creation of immutable and hashable proxy object from class instances,which implement access by index(it currently currently implemented with <code>Cython</code>).</li><li>Add support for access to recordclass object attributes by idiom: <code>ob['attrname']</code> (Issue #5).</li><li>Add argument <code>readonly</code> to recordclass factory to produce immutable namedtuple.In contrast to <code>collection.namedtuple</code> it use same descriptors as forregular recordclasses for performance increasing.</li></ul><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">0.7</h4><a id="user-content-07" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: 0.7" href="#07"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><ul dir="auto"><li>Make mutabletuple objects creation faster.
